comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: B - I - N - G - O !! The big white ship is the SS KAISER WILHELM II. Norddeutschen Lloyd NDL line. Launched 1889, renamed HOHENZOLLERN (II) in 1900, stranded in 1908 and broken up in Italy. Wikipedia (in German) - de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaiser_Wilhelm_II._(Schiff,_1889) with great hi-res photo for comparison and proof. Full description of her first visit to Sydney SMH 26/11/1889 p.5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13750894 . At the end - " ... The vessel will be berthed at the Circular Quay, at the south-eastern part ... " She was there for about a week. I vote for November 1889 for the date of this photo.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
May be wrong with that 1889 date since the YALLEROI is moored where they are building those wharves in the photo below - ie the main photo must be later than the first visit of the K-W II. 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8110724910/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The building of the new Manly and Watsons Bay wharves (completed December 1891) might give a clue to the date. The KAISER WILHELM II was in Sydney in March and December 1891; the December dates are too late to correspond to the state of the new wharves, so I think the March visit is more likely. Arrived 12/3/1891 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13817237 - "... The steamer will go up to the Sutherland Dock this morning, and to-morrow will be floated out and come to a berth at the company's new wharf, formerly that used by the P. and O. Company. ..." [ie SE side of Circular Quay] Departed 24/3/1891 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13818249 [top of col.3] So due to the tug and the Blue Peter flag ("about to leave", see note) this might be Tuesday 24 March 1891. Or not?

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] AMAZING level of detail here Beachcomber, thanks for the id on KAISER WILHELM II! I've spent the morning reading up on all the details you've provided :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Ha! Sorry to wreck your morning!  The ship must have been a truly fantastic sight in its day,  one of the largest and whitest.  I am surprised that there are not more photos around;  maybe now we know what we are looking at, the KAISER WILHELM II will crop up again.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] There certainly aren't many of this vessel in our collection, at least where it is identified. The white will make it stand out, I guess P&O weren't the first to start that trend!
